xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This study received financial support from the 90th ANNIVERSARY OF CHULALONGKORN UNIVERSITY FUND (Ratchadaphiseksomphot Endowment Fund) and the Center of Excellence on Hazardous Substance Management (HSM) , Chulalongkorn University . The authors would like to thank Mr. Krip Rojanastien, Chiva-Som International Health Resort , and Preserve Hua Hin, for the generous supports on research activities, and Dr. Attasit Korchaiyapruk for his valuable comments and suggestions. The author would also thank Ms. Kraisri Srithupthai from Rajamangala University of Technology Isan Sakonnakhon campus , Dr. Nipharat Sriprasert from Rajamangala University of Technology Rattanakosin Wangkraikangwon Campus , and Mr.Tatthap Veeratat for their field trip supports.

organization.$: International Postgraduate Programs in Environmental Management
Center of Excellence on Hazardous Substance Management (HSM)

head.citation-title: Multiple-criteria decision analysis to promote recycling activities at different stages of urbanization
head.abstracts: © 2016 Elsevier LtdThis study takes a holistic approach to provide decision support for selecting recycling practices that are suitable for urban settlement without mandatory recycling, such as Thailand. The study employed analytic hierarchical process (AHP) to nominate the most optimal informal recycling modes for municipal solid waste (MSW), namely, itinerant recyclable buying (IRB), recycling center buying (RCB), and donation to charity (DOC). Studies of MSW characteristic at landfills, willingness to pay and recycling attitudes using questionnaire surveys (n = 1063), and reviews of existing MSW management system were carried out in three urban settlements, classified as peri-urban (PS), urban (US), and metropolis (MS), that differ in size and administrative capacity in Thailand. Findings from the above studies were then used for creating AHP's evaluating criteria as willingness to recycle (WTR), potential reduction of landfill cost (C-MSW), and additional willingness to pay for the implementation of a recycling system (A-WTP). For WTR, we found that recycling modes with monetary return, IRB and RCB, remained the preferred venue of recycling as they consistently ranked higher than non-monetary return option (DNO) in all sites. For C-MSW, the result indicated that the choice of IRB were able to save the cost of waste management as IRB tended to induce highest diversion rates in all three sites. For A-WTP, the study found that respondents who opted to recycle via IRB were often commended the highest WTP compared to other mode of recycling in all sites. The final AHP scores (PS:IRB = 0.75,RCB = 0.13; US:IRB = 0.56; RCB = 0.35; MS: IRB = 0.65; RCB = 0.13) for all sites indicated that IRB was the most optimal option to promote recycling. Therefore, itinerant recyclable buying is a recommended option for all urban settlements as an effective, informal MSW collection activity.

classification.classification-description: Computer Software, Data Handling and Applications

grant-text.$: This study received financial support from the 90th ANNIVERSARY OF CHULALONGKORN UNIVERSITY FUND (Ratchadaphiseksomphot Endowment Fund) and the Center of Excellence on Hazardous Substance Management (HSM), Chulalongkorn University. The authors would like to thank Mr. Krip Rojanastien, Chiva-Som International Health Resort, and Preserve Hua Hin, for the generous supports on research activities, and Dr. Attasit Korchaiyapruk for his valuable comments and suggestions. The author would also thank Ms. Kraisri Srithupthai from Rajamangala University of Technology Isan Sakonnakhon campus, Dr. Nipharat Sriprasert from Rajamangala University of Technology Rattanakosin Wangkraikangwon Campus, and Mr.Tatthap Veeratat for their field trip supports.

coredata.dc:description: This study takes a holistic approach to provide decision support for selecting recycling practices that are suitable for urban settlement without mandatory recycling, such as Thailand. The study employed analytic hierarchical process (AHP) to nominate the most optimal informal recycling modes for municipal solid waste (MSW), namely, itinerant recyclable buying (IRB), recycling center buying (RCB), and donation to charity (DOC). Studies of MSW characteristic at landfills, willingness to pay and recycling attitudes using questionnaire surveys (n = 1063), and reviews of existing MSW management system were carried out in three urban settlements, classified as peri-urban (PS), urban (US), and metropolis (MS), that differ in size and administrative capacity in Thailand. Findings from the above studies were then used for creating AHP's evaluating criteria as willingness to recycle (WTR), potential reduction of landfill cost (C-MSW), and additional willingness to pay for the implementation of a recycling system (A-WTP). For WTR, we found that recycling modes with monetary return, IRB and RCB, remained the preferred venue of recycling as they consistently ranked higher than non-monetary return option (DNO) in all sites. For C-MSW, the result indicated that the choice of IRB were able to save the cost of waste management as IRB tended to induce highest diversion rates in all three sites. Therefore, itinerant recyclable buying is a recommended option for all urban settlements as an effective, informal MSW collection activity.
